content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with expertise in technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds will be assigned or hired. Support for the Office will be provided within various components of the Department, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection and U.S. Immigration and Customs. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will coordinate the Department's activities and appoint liaisons within various components of the Department to support the Office. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will coordinate the Department's activities to counter violent extremism and appoint liaisons within various components of the Department. Responsibilities include identifying risk factors and populations targeted by violent extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will coordinate activities to counter violent extremism by identifying risk factors, populations targeted, managing outreach, ensuring valid research informs activities, and developing a Department-wide strategy. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates activities to counter violent extremism by ensuring valid research informs counter-messaging programs using various technologies and social media platforms. The plan includes leveraging Internet, digital, and social media platforms to counter violent extremism, incorporating best practices from various partners, engaging in outreach activities, and using cooperative agreements with relevant departments and agencies. The Department's plan includes engaging in outreach activities, using cooperative agreements with relevant departments, and developing metrics to evaluate programs to counter violent extremism while respecting privacy and civil liberties. The Department's plan includes developing metrics to evaluate programs to counter violent extremism while respecting privacy and civil liberties. Additionally, they are identifying new research requirements and disseminating information to relevant stakeholders. The Department coordinates countering violent extremism activities with other Federal agencies and NGOs, serves as the primary representative for international issues, provides guidance on grant usage, and administers grant programs in collaboration with FEMA. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates with FEMA to administer grants for countering violent extremism. A memorandum of understanding outlines their roles in grant administration. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA, establishes a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program targeting violent extremism to congressional committees within 90 days of enactment. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program targeting violent extremism to congressional committees, including eligibility criteria, application process, grant award methodology, and monitoring. Community groups funding violent extremist activities are ineligible for grants. An annual report will be submitted to Congress for the next five fiscal years. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress for the next five fiscal years, detailing the Department's programs, policies, budget, and staff dedicated to countering violent extremism. The annual report to Congress by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will include details on the Department's budget, full-time and part-time staff dedicated to countering violent extremism programs, cooperation with other departments and agencies, and outcome-based metrics for evaluating program success. The annual report to Congress by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will include activities of the Office, outcome-based metrics for program success, outreach with organizations, grants awarded, training sponsored, and optimal personnel and funding levels. The annual report to Congress by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will include details on grants, training, personnel and funding levels, analysis of Department's activities, protection of civil rights and civil liberties, evaluation of grant program effectiveness, and incorporation of lessons learned from extremism programs. The Office of the Secretary authorizes $10,000,000 for Countering Violent Extremism annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 allocated for the grant program.
